ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.2_0: At that time the Buddha spoke to the monks in many ways about unattractiveness—he spoke in praise of unattractiveness, in praise of developing the mind in unattractiveness, and in praise of the attainment of unattractiveness.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.3_0: The Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.4_0: “Monks, I wish to go into solitary retreat for half a month.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.5_0: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my alms-food.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.6_0: “Yes, Venerable Sir,” they replied, and no one approached him except the one who brought him almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.7_0: The monks thought, “The Buddha has talked in many ways about unattractiveness,”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.8_0: and they devoted themselves to the development of the mind in unattractiveness in its many different facets.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.9_0: As a consequence, they became troubled by their own bodies, ashamed of them, disgusted with them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.10_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and had bathed their head. If the corpse of a snake or a dog or a human were hung around their neck, they’d be horrified, repelled, and disgusted.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.11_0: just so those monks were troubled by their own bodies.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.12_0: They took their own lives, took the lives of one another,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.15_0: This bowl and these robe will be yours.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.16_0: Then Migalaṇḍika took his bowl and robes and went to the newly ordained monks. He spent no more,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.17_0: and while he was washing it, he became anxious and remorseful:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.19_0: I’ve made much demerit by killing virtuous monks.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.20_0: Then, walking across the water, a god from the realm of the lord of death said to Migalaṇḍika,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.21_0: “Well done, superior man, you’re truly fortunate.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.22_0: You’ve made much merit, because you’ve brought across those who hadn’t yet crossed.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.24_0: “So it seems that I’m fortunate, that I’ve made much merit.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.25_0: I’ve taken a grass, sir, from the dwelling to one side, and say,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.26_0: “Who hasn’t crossed yet? Whom do I bring across?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.27_0: The monks who still had sensual desire became fearful and terrified, with their hair standing on end.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.28_0: Only those who were free from desires were unaffected.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.1.29_0: Then, on a single day, Migalaṇḍika killed one monk, two monks, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, even sixty monks.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.4_0: And how is it so developed and cultivated?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.5_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.18_0: They practice breathing in freeing the mind. They practice breathing out freeing the mind.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.19_0: When breathing in, he trains in contemplating impermanence; when breathing out, he trains in contemplating impermanence.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.3.20_0: They practice breathing in observing fading away. They practice breathing out observing fading away.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.4.1_0: Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.4.2_0: “Is it true, monks, that some monks have taken their own lives, have killed one another, and have said to Migalaṇḍika,

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj3:1.4.6_0: “Monks, it’s not suitable for these monks, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it should not be done.
